message: Someone out there has to be using Python 2.7 on Centos 5 in parallel with Python 2.4.  Do you just say screw RPMs?  Do you have spec files you're hoarding?  Any tips for creating a make altinstall RPM?
I am at the point where I compile python2.7 into /opt/python2.7, add pip, distribute, and virtualenv. I then tar up the results and create a really light spec file which produces an RPM.
@khightower that's what we've been discussing doing lately as well.
"rpmbuild -tb Python-2.7.1.tar.bz2" almost works and would create RPMs that can be installed alongside bundled 2.4 ones

We've been running Python 2.5 built that way for a long time - though I see that 2.7 one may need a bit of tweaking due to "Installed (but unpackaged) file(s) found", probably due to file changes in 2.7 without matching .spec updates.
At work Internally our sysadmins have created RPMs for a ton of python version, sadly that's not OpenSource I'll see if we can release them as it shouldn't be a big issue.
That said I believe the people at fedora are working on it. You should get in contact with "Dave Malcolm" <dmalcolm@redhat.com> he is the guy in charge of that.
